oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Prestige or Peril: The Experiences of Three Black Women Doctoral Students at Predominately White Institutions
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Garrett, Ramarra
Taylor, Michelle
Brown, Anglesia
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Black Feminist thought
care work
sister circles
Black Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This collaborative autoethnographic research aimed to explore the experiences of three Black women higher education practitioners who were full-time doctoral students at a predominantly white institution (PWI) in the Midwest. The women chose Sister Circles Methodology (SCM) as their methodological approach, which focuses on centering Black women's lived experiences and voices. The participants engaged in six sister circle sessions in various modes and settings, discussing a range of topics that included family dynamics, the meaning of Black womanhood, navigating doctoral studies, and workplace dynamics. Black Feminist Thought (BFT) was utilized to provide the theoretical foundation for this research endeavor. BFT emphasizes the ethic of caring and personal responsibility and provides a strong foundation for guiding and grounding discussions. Overall, the research provides valuable insights into the nuanced challenges and experiences of Black women pursuing doctoral degrees, highlighted the importance of centering their voices in research, and provided implications for doctoral programs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Journal of African American Women and Girls in Education; Vol. 5 No. 2 (2025): Winter 2025; 39-64
